Longevity diet:

1. Eat a mostly vegan diet with some fish: Strive for a 100 percent
plant-and fish-based diet, but limit fish consumption to two or three meals a
week and avoid fish with high mercury content. After age sixty-five to
seventy, if you start losing muscle mass, strength, and weight, add more fish
and fruit and introduce animal-based foods like eggs, cheese, and yogurt
made from sheep’s or goat’s milk.
2. Consume low but sufficient proteins: Consume approximately 0.31 to
0.36 grams of protein per pound of body weight per day. If you weigh 100
pounds, that is about 31 to 36 grams of protein per day, of which 30 grams
should be consumed in a single meal to maximize muscle synthesis. If you
weigh 200 pounds and have 35 percent body fat, 60 grams of protein per day
are instead sufficient, considering that it is the lean body mass that utilizes
most of the proteins. Protein intake should be raised slightly after age sixtyfive to seventy in individuals who are losing weight and muscle.
3. Minimize bad fats and sugars, and maximize good fats and
complex carbs: The diet should be rich in “good” unsaturated fats,
including those from salmon, almonds, and walnuts, but very poor in “bad”
saturated, hydrogenated, and trans fats. Likewise, the diet should be rich in
complex carbohydrates, such as those provided by whole bread and
vegetables, but poor in sugars and limited in pasta, rice, white bread, fruit
juices, and fruits containing carbohydrates that are easily converted into
simple sugars. Finally, the diet should be low in animal proteins but
relatively high in vegetable proteins, in order to minimize the former’s
negative effects on diseases and maximize the latter’s nourishing effects.

[1/3]

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
4. Be nourished: The body needs protein, essential fatty acids (omega-3 and
omega-6), minerals, vitamins, and sufficient sugar to fight the many wars
going on inside and outside cells. To be sure you get enough nutrients, every
three days take a multivitamin and a mineral pill, plus an omega-3 fish oil
soft gel purchased from a reputable manufacturer.
5. Eat at the table of your ancestors: Consume a variety of foods to take
in all the required nutrients, but choose the ones that were common on the
table of your parents, grandparents, and great-grandparents, so long as they
are included in the Longevity Diet.
6. Eat twice a day plus a snack: Unless your waist circumference and
body weight are in the normal or low range, it is best to eat breakfast plus
one other meal a day and one low-calorie, low-sugar, nourishing snack. If
your weight or muscle mass is too low, then eat three meals a day plus a
snack.
7. Time-restricted eating: Restrict your eating to eleven to twelve hours or
less per day. For example, if you eat breakfast after 8 a.m., finish dinner
before 8 p.m. Shorter periods of feeding (ten hours or less) have been shown
to be even more effective in promoting health, but they are much more
difficult to comply with and may increase the risk of side effects, such as the
formation of gallstones.

[2/3]

"What this means is that after initializing a Cesium clock, and leaving it alone for a day, it should be correct to within about 5 parts in 1014, or 4 nanoseconds. Relativistic effects are huge compared to this."

but this is misleading. He never gives an approximation of the time difference due to time dilation.

Lets say, like I did before, that the GPS satellite is going 4km/h at an altitude of 20200km above the earth due the relativistic time dilation the correction will be

(1-sqrt(1-(4km/s)^2/(speed of light)^2))*20200km/(speed of light) = 6ps

so the supposed error from time dilation is the same as the excepted clock drifting for 2 minutes after being synchronized.

Now if you google it GPS satellites are synchronized every 8 to 24 hours, so accounting for time dilation is useless. The clocks drift more and rounding or instrumentation error will be much bigger factors.

You know, scientists actually don't know. The traditional non rotating black holes everyone learns about in pop sci probably don't exist. It difficult to imagine a gravitationally bound object not having angular momentum from its formation. Ringularities have two horizons for which the inner covers another ergosphere. Since ergospheres can accelerate mass faster than light, it's not impossible that you can leave a black hole. Penrose diagrams show the exit of a black hole would put you in a universe that isn't the one you came from. It would look like you would emerge from a white hole but with the unlikely exception of the big bang, such objects don't exist.

Just keep in mind that the radiation from the accretion disk would vaporize you long before you ever got close to the event horizon so suffice to say, any discussion of near or in can only be a mathematical depictions.

Scientist believes that a supermassive black hole is at the center of galaxy with a mass that is millions or billions of times that of the Sun and that its enormous gravitational force is responsible for keeping all the stars inna galaxy together.

However, the core of the galaxy cluster Abell 2261, located about 2.7 billion light-years from Earth, appears to disprove the theory.

There, the rules of astrophysics indicate that there should be a huge black monster of between 3,000 and 100,000 million solar masses, comparable to the weight of some of the largest known. However, no matter how many times researchers search relentlessly, there is no way to find it.

The latest observations with NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory and the Hubble Space Telescope only delve into the mystery.

Astronomers have found no definitive evidence of black hole recovery, and it is unknown if the supermassives get close enough to produce gravitational waves and merge. So far, they have only verified the collapse of much smaller objects. The discovery of a larger one that recedes encourages scientists to search for gravitational waves from merging supermassive black holes.

During a merger, the supermassive black hole in each galaxy descends toward the center of the recently merged galaxy. If they are held together by gravity and their orbit begins to shrink, the black holes are expected to interact with surrounding stars and expel them from the center of the galaxy. This explains the large core of Abell 2261.

The authors concluded that either there is no black hole in any of these places, or that it is attracting material too slowly to produce a detectable X-ray signal.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Been learning measure theory and the Caratheodory trick of measurable sets is just amazing
> Take any set and any outer measure defined on this set. Then the collection of measurable sets (in the sense of caratheodory) not only forms a sigma algebra, but the outer measure restricted on these measurable sets (the new sigma algebra) satisfies the properties of a true measure.
a really profound theorem, since the outer measure is nearly perfect and satisfies many desired properties, but is sadly not countably additive (only subadditive). you can also complete existing measure spaces by adding null sets
> Take a measure defined on a sigma algebra, and extend the sigma algebra by forming all sets that are a union of a set from the sigma algebra with a null set (a null set is a subset of a set with measure zero). This new collection is a sigma algebra, which contains the original sigma algebra plus all the null sets. Defining a new measure which preserves the mapping of the old one when restricted to the original sigma algebra, will still be a measure on the new collection. This new measure space is complete, meaning every set contained in a null set will also be part of the collection.
what this entails is that one may add 'negligible' null sets to a measure space without sacrificing any meaningful properties of the measure space. This is precisely what differs the borel sigma algebra on the real line from the lebesgue measurable sets, and completing the borel algebra leads to the lebesgue measurable sets. On both sets one has a measure, which is nearly the same. Most sets one has to deal with are borel sets, but this is no problem since the extended measure does not measure the 'size' if the sets any larger.
Share your favourite measure theory facts here.

threads.com:
What's your take on the Grabby Aliens Model? According to it, as soon as an expansionary alien civilization arises, all systems they get their hands on will be inevitably colonized by them. No new intelligence life has a chance to evolve because every planet gets occupied by space-faring advanced life. This constitutes a selection effect.

Therefore, expansionary aliens sets a deadline for other natural-born intelligence species to ever appear.

The model can also be used to predict the speed of aggressive expansion. If we could see aliens in our sky, it would be evidence that they expand slowly. If they expand really fast, you wouldn't see them until they are in your face. The lack of evidence for alien activity even on nearby galaxy through our telescope, counterintuitively, implies a diabolically fast rate of expansion (a third of the speed of light).

The implication is that alien civilization that will be born naturally are and will be born in a very short time window after which no more natural evolutions will occur. Simulations of the model indicate that the rare earliest civilizations would have also the chance to expand wider both because of lack of competition and the universe being smaller in size. As much as 30%-50% of the universe's volume, each controlling [math]10^5 - 3x10^7[/math] galaxies could be already colonized, and we could face them in an estimate of 500 million years.

This offers an explanation for our apparent earliness in the history of the universe. There are no aliens nearby because otherwise we wouldn't be here.

Why do they take so long ?
Why do they cost so much ?
Can AI help speed things up ?

The cost of developing a drug is typically over $1 billion dollars, sometimes over $2 billion

The patients they trial the drugs on are usually only paid a few hundred dollars too, and there's only maybe 20 to 30 of them, so $30k

I get the feeling a lot of money is wasted in these trials and they could probably be significantly streamlined. The admin costs almost seem like it's a way for pharmaceutical companies to launder large amounts of cash or something

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15005158
This hits it pretty well, but I'll tackle something here:
>Can AI help speed things up ?
I actually work in the ML in drug discovery field. AI has sped up the early drug discovery process 100%, we've seen 1000x hit rate on finding new potential therapeutics using ML. Beyond hit-to-lead, however, it's kinda bunk.
That said, new types of models (generative approaches) can boost that even more, but we're roadblocked by old-ass medicinal chemists who wont even try to trust the results. I see it go like this: generative model output -> medicinal chemist picks what goes forward. The problem- the point of the generative model is to produce shit the medicinal chemist would never pick, so that it's potentially patentable and would be novel. There obvious situation where you might have something super reactive/very obviously insoluble, but that's why we input those parameters into the generative model.
We contract with drug discovery companies and have found that the bigger the company, the farther behind they are on using new tooling (weirdly enough, despite the many cutting-edge publications that come from these companies in the ML space, they actually don't use the ML in production- they don't trust it enough and still do the old school route of people-only decision making).
We've been able to actually speed past a few big companies because we use the ML properly for discovery purposes. The main problem for us is sparse datasets: it's expensive as hell to generate data for drug binding, etc. and most companies keep their results private.
There are some larger efforts to predict whether a molecule will fail/succeed at clinical trial which involves a massive data mining procedure to collect stats on every drug submitted to clinical trials and whether they passed or not and at what phase and why. Huge, huge dataset that requires graph-based approaches to tackle. However, as you might expect, that's behind closed doors, so we can't consume it.

>Why wouldn't you choose to play Poker if you know statistics so well?

That answers why playing online is a bad idea, solvers are a thing.
Live poker is one avenue to go, but the softest games are also home games where you're paranoid about cheating at every turn. Live games in a casino can be beaten, but you not only have to be better than your opponents, you have to be good enough to also overcome the rake. Not to mention all the variance in the game, got your money in good? Great, your opponent just rivered a boat and now you get to go fill in that hole you just dug with a plastic spoon instead of the excavator you dug it with.
There are professional gamblers out there, but the good ones are finding bigger edges, or at least small edges where the game moves at a faster pace than 30 rounds per hour. Even the tiny little 1% edge you get from card counting and spreading your bets is better than that, because at least you can play at a lightning fast pace and earn more in EV, even if it means getting tossed with some regularity.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15009517
If you can simulate an event horizon and you find something interesting happening, that tells you that the interesting thing is a product of your existing physics. You won't be discovering any new phenomena specific to black holes if you only ever use analogs, but you can discover new phenomena that exist in your model which can be a very useful result in itself. It's still true that direct experiments are the best, but how much weight they carry depends on the hypothesis being tested.

Suppose you find superconductivity in some sample and come up with a mathematical model that describes it. Both great discoveries, but one is far more useful from a practitioners perspective. But you need both, because you'll only find new phenomena that don't fit your models by going out there and measuring it.

threads.sub: A /sci/ Game Theory Challenge: 7-ballot inside joke
threads.com:
There are 7 participants in this vote, who each get a ballot and are allowed to cast one vote for every contestant including themselves on their ballot. (So each ballot can be used to assign 7 votes and each vote is a point) The topic of the vote is negative and so the aim is to not get the highest number of votes. You do not want to win the vote. However, A and B have dared each other to try and get the highest vote. Everybody else is voting honestly. In other words, A and B are both competing with one another for the negative outcome and will use strategy, while everyone else will cast genuine ballots. For A and B winning is the most desired outcome. But both would rather draw than lose (So the expected outcomes are Win= 1 Draw= 0 and Losing= -1 for A and B). For the other 5 voters not winning is the most desired outcome. (Loss and draw= 1 and win= -1)
So to make a Nash Equilibrium between A and B possible we will assume that the only contestants able to vote for themselves are A and B, and nobody else will vote for themselves, as they do not want to give themselves a point. However, everyone else can be assumed to cast a random ballot other than that. So, another contestant can make any possible combination of votes as long as it does not include their own name.
So... How would A and B distribute their votes to achieve Nash Equilibrium?

I am sorry if this was not explained clearly. If not I will clear anything up. The immediate common sense answer I had was that A casts a vote for A and B casts a vote for B, leaving the rest up to chance. But when I tried to work this out and prove it I realized that this problem filtered me hard. So I would love to see how you guys approach this.
